segments.text: Testing, testing, this is a test, this is a test.
Let me just stop.
That's quite okay.
Today's interview is with Brigadier General Travis M. Hetherington.
Today's Tuesday, August 12, 1980.
Let's start with your upbringing.
You were born in Reagan, Texas, February 20, 1908.
Can you tell us about your father?
Well, my dad...
My mother and dad lived on a farm south of Reagan, Texas, about two miles.
And my father was born in Alabama, and he came to Texas with my grandmother and grandfather when he was about four years old.
And they settled in Falls County, along with
around six brothers and two sisters.
Why'd they come from Alabama?
Well, it's hard to say.
I mean, I don't really know.
It seemed to me in visiting Monroeville, Alabama, where my dad was born, that everybody was
going to new territories, getting new land and that was just the way it was.
Now why they came to Falls County I don't know because it seemed to me that Falls County is probably the poorest part of Texas.
And of course after the war, after the Civil War, apparently the schools were all broken
And my dad, well, I think he went through the eighth grade or something of this sort.
And the same thing applied to my mother.
How many acres did your father have on his ranch?
Well, he had, oh, I think around 290 acres.
It was really a farm.
It was a cotton and corn farm.
Okay, cotton and corn.
Let me start.
Okay, we're doing fine as far as that's concerned now.
290 acres, what kind of livelihood could you make off that?
Well, it was very nice as far as I was concerned.
I had two brothers and two sisters.
I had one older brother who was about 15 months older than I, and then I had a younger brother that was about three years younger than I.

And of course when you have your own cows and your own meat and your own hogs and your own vegetable garden and why there isn't much to buy other than sugar and at one time why we even had sugar cane on the farm and we
had a cane mill and a horse drawn with one horse running around and so we ran the cane through the press and then we cooked it out and made syrup.
And of course my dad peddled beef on almost every Saturday.
When I was growing up we would slaughter a yearling on
Friday afternoon, Friday night, cut it up, and then he would take it to Reagan in a horse-drawn wagon.
He had a beef enclosure on the back, and he just paled his beef.
Now this is a time, a little bit earlier than this, was the time of populism.
and populism was a fairly strong force in Texas.
Did he ever talk about politics and populism?
No, no.
You never discussed politics?
No, no.
I think he was more concerned about making a living.
Sure.
And we really never did get into any big discussion about politics.
Of course, later on, when John L. Lewis was a strong man in the

coal miner being chief of the coal mine union while he was very verbose and being against the coal miners and things of this sort, trying to get more money when he thought everybody should make a living off the land, I guess.
What kind of education did he have?
I don't really remember, but I'm sure he only went through about sixth or seventh grade.
He was very good at mathematics and being a merchant type of thing.
He was very, very honest.
As far as I know, he never cheated anybody out of a nickel.
He was very, very honest.
and of course he peddled his watermelons.
I mean he loved to go to town and he loved to talk, so everybody knew him of course.
And he had a lot of good friends in the buy-in, Mr. Robbins in the blacksmith shop and Mr. Wesley Shonfield who was in the grocery business.
Now, you have a master's degree in business.
Did he ever stress education with you?
Well, both my mother and dad and us growing up, their objective was that we graduate from high school.
I mean, that was really their objective.
They insisted that we were going to stay in school if it took us 25 years to do it, to graduate from high school.
And then, of course, when I graduated from high school,
He said, this is where I stop and you begin.
And he said, if you ever need some money and need to borrow some money to do whatever you want to do, he would go on my note, but as far as he would go.
So they insisted we go to Ann also.
Mother was primarily the individual who saw that we got our lessons.
And of course, she helped us out as long as we were in the lower grades.
But when we got in the higher grades, it got beyond her capability, although she was well-read.
I mean, she read everything she'd get her hands on.
She wasn't really educated as far as mathematics and algebra and all that type of thing was concerned.
Let's talk about the farm for a minute.
You raised cotton.
Did you have sharecroppers on to do this, or did you do it yourselves?
No, we did this ourselves.
In our younger years, we had what I call old Lewis and Liza.
He was quite a character.
He had been in jail a number of times.
And he had around his wrist, just like the palm of your hand, and around his ankles, just like the palm of your hand.
It was where he had had chains on.
And he had one ear that had been bitten off while he was in jail.
Bitten off?
Bitten off, yeah.
Pretty mean jail.
Well, that's right.
Somebody was hungry.
Well, he'd gotten in a fight.
But anyway, he had gotten out.
Are you a coffee drinker?
Please.
And so he worked in Chopcott, and he was a real good
I mean, he was a real good worker.
I mean, boy, he could just kind ofand so he kind of took care of us boys.
And the thing that you remember is going down to his house and sitting on his front porch eating cheese and crackers and lemonade, yeah.
Well, at least he liked to work.
So the things you remember is a very strange thing because I said go down to his house and he had probably a one-room or two-room cabin that was on the place.
It was on your father's farm?
Yeah.
He was a sharecropper.
Well, he didn't really share.
He worked by the day.
He was a day worker.
He was a day worker.
Paul, I don't know, Dad paid him so much money.
hundred pounds of cotton he picked or so much per day.
And gave him a place to stay?
And gave him a place to stay.
And of course he was an alcoholic.
I mean they were saying tonight why he was going to get drunk and you knew that, but the rest of the week why he was just as good as you could find anywhere.
But your father got in the wagon and went after him every time he didn't show up.
He found him in town drunk in jail or something.
Why was he in jail to begin with?
Why was he in prison?
Oh, I think he had killed somebody.
But as far as we were concerned, as far as I was concerned, as far as my dad was concerned, he was just as safe as you could find.
What did you learn from this man?
Well, I would say that you learned how to work.
Well, I don't know if you learned a lot, but the fact that he got out and I don't know if he was married or not, he at least lived with somebody.
But anyway, he could chop cotton and so he was always out in front of us boys.
Do you remember what you thought of him?
Well, what I thought of him, I just thought he was a fine individual.
And I think that your compassion for individuals who are not as straight in there as you are is increased.
I think maybe that's what you, starting out your early life, I think that probably is
It helps you out in your later... Did your relationship with him have any impact on your later thoughts about black Americans?
No, I don't...
I think in growing up, why... Well, I think it shows that everybody's not all bad or all good.
I mean, even that man was not all bad.
Well, later on, I mean, the...
The boys who lived closest to us were, their last name was Cross.
George and I and his two oldest boys were about the same age and they always came up and we played together and made toys out of corn cobs.
And later on, when we got a little wagon or tricycle, we rode it down the hill that was next to our house.
And I think it was no different from what you, the integration type of thing.
In fact, I think it was.
So the Crosses were a black family?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
And he later on became a sharecropper for us, for my dad.
And because we had moved from where I was born to the house where my grandmother and grandmother, grandfather and grandmother, mother Hetherington had lived.
And when they passed away, by then my dad moved into their house and the Crosses moved into where we lived.
I think it developed the fact that you had no animosity against color or because they were, as far as I was concerned, just as equal as we were.
And they played with us, our toys, and we played with their toys.
So you grew up in an integrated society then, unlike so many other Texans.
Well, you do because you're in a little small town.
We were out and on a farm.

And we of course had the Kirkpatricks that lived right up the street from us and they were white and we probably had a total of around four or five boys who were in the same age group as we, so we played with them.
And we played with them.
You were really younger when you were in the five, six, seven, eight year old.
You were playing with the crosses and what have you.
But later on, when you got to be a teenager, we had about six.
boys that we went hunting together and chased jackrabbits and went duck hunting, all this type of thing.
Many people grow up in a society that has both races, especially in the South, yet they don't grow up to have feelings and
that you've expressed, that is, that they're just as equal as we were.
How can you account for the feeling that you obtained?
Well, I think it's the same today.
My grandchildren are in school with your
And they make no difference or differentiation between whether or not the individual is white or whether or not he's black.
Do you think your father, your parents had anything to do with your attitudes?
Well, I would say so.
I mean, there's no question about it.
If they had talked about or downgraded
the Lewis, old Lewis, or if they were afraid of him, or if they ever expressed any animosity towards him.
But as far as my dad was concerned, as far as my mother was concerned, they really didn't make any difference between them.
Okay, let's talk about your mother.
Did you tell me about her?
Well, she was born in Texas.
Her father had come from, well, we're trying to find out.
We think Kentucky, Paducah, Kentucky.
And they had moved to Roberson County, which is next door to Falls County.
And she was the youngest, I think, of a big family.
She had about, I don't know if I'd have to count them, seven brothers and one sister.
And she grew up around Bremont, which is about six, eight miles from there.
And then, I don't know how my mother and dad met, but anyway, they were married, I guess, in around 1905 or somewhere along that.
What kind of person was she?
What kind of personality or character was she?
Oh, she was a real strong individual.
I would say she was a dominating type of individual.
a type of individual that wouldn't hold us kids back.
I mean, when we graduated from high school, a lot of mothers hang on.
But whatever we decided to do, that was all right with her.
And she expressed her opinion quite readily.
And so...
And she kept house and I don't ever remember her working in the fields at all.
She took care of cooking the meals and cleaning the house and keeping her clothes clean and things of this sort.
And my dad took care of providing for us all.
Now you say she was a strong individual.
Would you consider her the authority in the household?
Well, I think to keep peace in the family, I think my dad gave in a lot.
They really didn't fight very much.
I mean, it was rather calm.
But she was always saying, George, do this.
George, do that.
or George bring in the vegetables.
Who had the final word?
Well, I don't know.
It's hard to say whether she had a final word or not, but she always had her own couple of cows.
that she sold a year and got herself some money, which was her money.
Oh, really?
That's kind of unusual back in the early 1900s, isn't it?
So she raised her own cattle right there?
Well, he took care of them, of course, but she had her own cows, and there was only about two or three.
she didn't accumulate a lot of money.
And then of course she loved flowers, so she could spend her egg money and her cow money on whatever she wanted to.
And so she bought flowers and flower seeds and pots and this type of thing.
So she worked in the yard.
And she sold and
made a lot of things for for the for us boys and also for our my sisters as when they grew up.
What about your father?
What kind of personality or character was he?
Well very kind, very I would say very generous.
Never really raised a lot of heck.
I mean far as
Spankin's a concern.
There's very few, I'd say.
Not that we didn't need them.
We all need them.
No, I would say we had a very calm household.
Okay, let's look at it this way.
You've had a very successful career.
In which ways would you consider that your parents were responsible for that?
Well, I would say insisting
on going to school, that we attend school, not play hooky.
You and Dad not play hooky.
And met reasonably good grades.
They really didn't push us as far as making A's or B's or C's as long as we passed.
And they always said that if we ever got a whipping at school, we were going to get another one at home.
I only got one whipping at school and they never knew about it.
So I would say insisting on us getting through high school and then after getting through high school not really voicing any objection for permitting me to do whatever I wanted to do.

And I figured, well of course when you are growing up, why your main objective is to graduate my school, you figure that when you graduate my school that would be all the education that you'd ever want or need.
And of course after graduating and then along came the fall while I was ready to go to school, so I went to Tyler Commercial College.
which is about a seven month course, and my dad went on a note at the First National Bank of Reagan, Texas for the tuition, and I went over and entered school.
Now my older brother, after he graduated from high school, he stayed at home and worked on the farm for a year.
you were really torn as to whether or not you should do the same thing.
Well, I didn't.
I decided I was going to have to go to Tyler Commercial College.
And of course, in those days, I rode a train from Reagan to Tyler, and I think that was probably the first time I'd ever been on a train.
And in those days, I'm sure you understand that
Well, I imagine I was fourteen before my dad got his first automobile, so your severe of activity was really within about three or four miles of home.
Right.
And so the first time I ever visited Hearn, which is only thirty miles away, was after my dad got an automobile when I was about fifteen.
And Marlin, Texas, which was about 12 miles away, you never got up there.
And then after he got an automobile, then we went to the movies in Marlin.
But I would say that primarily is the fact that they insisted on us getting an education through high school.

the second thing is is not interfere with uh with our activities or what we want to do afterwards okay okay now you had two brothers two sisters right how'd you get along with them oh real well i mean we uh my three brothers my two brothers and i uh well we slept in the same bed for uh
I guess until we were twelve or thirteen.
And of course my younger brother was, after I left home, the year after I left home, he was killed on a hay rake.
And I was working at that time for Lawrence Grocery Company.
And of course your sisters, they were much younger and therefore
I guess you got along just about as well as any teenage boy gets along with kid sisters.
They always, my oldest sister, I think she was born in about 1915, and so I was about seven I guess when she was born.
The only thing I can remember about her is she always wanted the neck of a chicken, but she wouldn't eat the neck, the first piece.
It was always the last piece.
So we were always scrambling for the neck, but that was her piece of chicken.
But otherwise, by the time I was graduating from high school, she was just entering school.
So there's a large age difference.
Well, we thought it was a large age difference, but now it's really not a large age difference.
Many generals that I've talked to have expressed episodes in their early lives that they thought had a significant impact on their later career.
Do you have any episodes that might have had an impact on you?
Well, I would say that probably the character that your mother and dad has affects your life a lot.
I mean, I think that my dad being completely honest with all his dealings, didn't cheat anybody out of anything.
He loved to work.
And I think that the fact that he teaches you honesty and integrity and willingness to work, I think this is a big influence.
I mean, I think it's a shame today that your young boys can't get a job and work.
Yesterday, I was talking to a 16-year-old boy,
He just couldn't get a job anywhere.
By the time I was 16, I was picking 200 pounds of cotton a day.
And although you weren't getting a lot of allowances out of it, and you weren't being paid for doing it by the fact that he at least taught you that you liked to work.
And I think maybe I'm a workaholic.
Sure.
And I think that's your upbringing and your honesty that when you say something why you mean it and things of this sort.
Did religion play a role in your early life?
Well I would say religion the only activities that you had out of your
home was your Baptist young people's programs on Sunday evening.
My mother was a primitive Baptist and my father was a missionary Baptist.
So we joined the missionary Baptist church and we normally attended
the church on our own, really, except my mother's church every fourth Sunday, normally.
Of course, primitive Baptists are very primitive in their religion.
They don't have pianos, as you might know.
And they liked to sing, and the preachers liked to talk.
And I can remember sometimes it would be three preachers preaching.
The last guy would get up and say, I'm not going to say anything.
But an hour later, he was still talking.
And also, normally, mother and dad would bring home a big crowd of people.
